10 E-Commerce Entrepreneurs Are Excited To See
With the U.S. alone exceeding $1 trillion in e-commerce

in 2022, its no surprise that businesses are looking to innovate in the online shopping space. From more eco-friendly packaging options to implementing technology such as augmented reality and artificial intelligence, there are a number of growing trends that entrepreneurs and industry leaders are excited to see take off in the near future.
To share their own insights into the world of e-commerce, 10 members of
discuss some of the top e-commerce trends or innovations they're excited about lately, as well as the impact they see those trends having on their businesses or other businesses in the future.
1. The Rise Of Sustainable, Eco-Friendly Packaging

I am excited about the rise of sustainable and eco-friendly packaging in e-commerce. Consumers are increasingly concerned about the environmental impact of their purchases, and businesses are responding by adopting sustainable materials and minimizing packaging waste. By incorporating eco-friendly packaging solutions, other businesses can contribute to a greener future while appealing to environmentally conscious customers. This positive shift not only enhances your brand image, but it also drives long-term growth and success in a competitive market where customers value responsible business practices.
2. The Consistent Growth Of Mobile Commerce

Im really excited about mobile commerce right now. While this isnt necessarily a brand-new e-commerce trend, all of the numbers continue to grow year over yearwith no signs of slowing down in the foreseeable future. I expect this to have the most significant impact on smaller e-commerce shops. Theyll need to put more emphasis on driving mobile sales to compete with the bigger players and massive online marketplaces.

Lately I have seen many e-commerce sites offering live demos of the products before you buy them. This offers great visuals for the buyers, especially when they are buying a new product or something very expensive. I think soon it will become a trend because buyers want to see the real products. E-commerce businesses can offer this perk to their prime customers, which leads to hav
ing more customers on the site.

One-click checkout is a game-changer because it reduces the number of clicks and pages needed to complete a purchase, which in turn reduces cart abandonment rates and increases conversion rates. I believe this will have a huge impact on businesses in the future, as it improves the overall shopping experience and makes purchasing more seamless and efficient for customers. This will lead to increased customer satisfaction and loyalty, ultimately benefiting businesses in terms of revenue and growth. Furthermore, one-click checkout has the potential to become the industry standard for e-commerce, as it aligns with the increasing trend of simplifying and streamlining the customer journey.

A huge e-commerce trend in 2023 is the ability for new hardware innovations to be rapidly designed, prototyped and manufactured in short-batch production. This means that it is easier than ever for anyone with a physical product idea to go from concept to production in a short period of time and at a lower product development expense. New innovators can then leverage a variety of e-commerce strategies to launch their invention ideas to the market rapidly. It used to take years to develop new physical consumer product ideas and take them to market, but now new brands are developing and launching new products in under a year due to the advances in product development and rapid manufacturing.

Like many, we are excited about AIs use case within our business, primarily for two business functions: customer service and content creation. While AI won't fully be able to take over both of these functions due to the narrow niche of our business, it will certainly have an "Iron Man" effect, allowing our teams to service more customer inquiries faster with fewer resources. Plus, on the content side, it will serve as an excellent resource for first drafts. -

The most striking trend with great potential in my opinion is the rise of augmented reality (AR) in e-commerce. AR allows customers to view and judge products in a highly realistic and interactive way, with innovative features such as virtual try-ons and product customization. This technology is revolutionizing the way that consumers shop online, and early adopters of AR in e-commerce are likely to see an increase in customer engagement, buyer trust and, ultimately, sales. Moreover, this is just the beginning, and I expect many exciting developments as AR develops and integrates with other technologies like virtual reality and 3D web design. So, I believe augmented reality is the next big thing in e-commerce, and applying it effectively will surely offer a major competitive advantage for e-commerce businesses.

Live shopping software is probably the coolest development in the e-commerce sector. Since social media has become such an essential part of people's shopping behavior, these tools make it super easy for vendors to sell while they are live on multiple platforms and for customers to purchase during the presentation. The software has great potential and encourages engagement between the two parties. -

I'm thrilled to see same-day delivery options becoming a new norm in the e-commerce world. Offering same-day delivery options not only provides instant gratification to customers, but it also sets businesses apart from their competitors. Plus, with the rise of on-demand services and delivery apps, it's easier than ever to make this a reality for customers. So if you're looking to stay ahead of the game, consider adding same-day delivery to your e-commerce arsenal.

With the emerging popularity of virtual assistants, we are starting to integrate a voice-enabled shopping experience into our new developments. Voice-enabled shopping is a growing e-commerce trend that involves using smart speakers and virtual assistants to make online purchases via voice commands. This trend is expected to increase the convenience and efficiency of online shopping for
consumers while presenting new opportunities and challenges for businesses. Companies that
embrace this trend and optimize their product listings for voice search are likely to benefit from its continued growth in popularity. According to Google, 27% of people use
search on mobile devices, making it clear that voice-
enabled shopping on our websites will provide us with a competitive advantage.
10 Common Problems Solved by E-commerce Software

The right e-commerce software solution will not only ease your workload, but solve common problems that may be limiting customer engagement. Online retailers of all sizes face similar roadblocks, and can turn to targeted e-commerce capabilities to solve them and increase sales.

Weve all been on confusing websitesthe kind that compel us to close the tab even if we like what theyre selling. Customers trust and respond to aesthetically pleasing pages and easy-to-navigate sites. Thats why common
like high-resolution images, product customization options (size and color), and intuitive search engines are top boosters in e-commerce products.
First-time buyers are more likely to turn into repeat customers when they sense they can engage with real people in your company, which is why many e-commerce solutions include comprehensive

toolkits. Built-in e-commerce service features like contact us buttons, customer service forms, or live chat features make you easily accessible and can help convert an unhappy shopper into a repeat client. Efficient

Online security is a stark reality that all of us have to deal with. Simply put, if your customers dont feel safe doing business with you, theyll look elsewhere. Picking an e-commerce software with robust
benefits both you and your clients. Common features of a secure online environment for retail include secure payment processing, transaction protection, and data encryption.

If you are unable to fill orders within a reasonable timeframe because of fulfillment bottlenecks, your online reputation and sales will suffer. Many online shoppers are dealing with late deliveries due to the increased stress of COVID-19, so it's good to be prepared. Popular top e-commerce software products will expedite the
with automated features that can generate and print packing slips, customer invoices, and shipping labels to speed your package on its way.

Receiving and processing customer payments is important to every business. Credit card transactions are an especially important part of online retail servicesyou will want to choose a trustworthy payment gateway platform that your customers can trust with their sensitive information. A recurring theme of e-commerce operations is ease-of-use. You need to make it as simple as possible for customers to buy your product, which means providing them with

. A lot of shopping is done on hand-held devicesif your website isnt optimized for mobile viewing, you will end up losing a lot of business. Many solutions offer services compatible with mobile devices and ensure support on a wide range of platforms such as iOS, Android, and various tablet brands.

Features that optimize market reach allow you to expand the scope of your business. There is no need to miss out on business because customers are located abroad. E-commerce marketing tools can help drive wider traffic to your products, and
can enable you to grow your online sales by expanding your base-target audience to potential customers across the world.
Online shopping carts are easy to fill and just as easy to abandon. Its common for people to browse sites, place items in their baskets, and then close the tab. Thats why many products come with
like transaction progress bars and remarketing campaigns to engage with customers that leave items in their carts by offering discounts or other perks.

can be of great value to businesses that have found the perfect solution but want to fill a few gaps. Software with integrations work seamlessly with external solutions for inventory management, communication, security, and more. Some products also allow you to create custom integrations through backend coding. A lot of e-commerce products are equipped with practical

to help manage complex supply chains to allow you and your partners to communicate more effectively. Replenishment tools help you preemptively stock your inventory, while a dedicated B2B e-commerce website simplifies the flow of orders between suppliers and businesses. The best B2B e-commerce platform solutions will come with self-service website functionalities to suit the needs of suppliers, and ultimately lead to timely deliveries and happy customers.
Design Thinking: How to Develop a New Product that Solves a Problem

When it comes to design thinking, the design isnt about website graphics or pretty animations. In design thinking, design is everything related to the person your end product is meant for, i.e., your customer.
Design thinking is a way of framing and directing the process of new product development. As a framework, design thinking adheres to a set of principles:
. Design thinking is always about people. A quality product solves a problem for the audience and fits into the context for which its intended, e.g., a persons commute, etc.

. There are two types of thinking required: divergent (quantitative) and convergent (qualitative). First, we work on the objective number of problems to identify or ideas well need to create, and then we use our best judgement to choose the right ones to address.
. Design thinkers accept their mistakes and do not hesitate to make them. And often, that mistake will lead to a break-through idea or an extraordinary decision.
. Its not a product but something that explains how the product works. It can be a short
, or just a hand-drawn picture on a whiteboard. The main thing is to explain what turns this product into a solution.

. When a prototype is ready, give it to someone else for feedback. Improve it. Then make it again. Testing and analyzing a prototype is cheaper than creating a first series for retail, and it protects your product from major failures after launch.

. So youve used the method of design thinking and developed the perfect product. Is that it? Far from it! First, everything can be improved. Second, your solution can become dated over time. Thats why savvy design thinkers periodically repeat the design thinking process to ensure theyve got the best possible product for their audiences problem at any given time.
: about 15 minutes per person, from 10 representatives of your target audience.
: a voice recorder, a video recorder.

Empathy is about understanding your customers and their lives  knowing what they do, think, and feel. Its not about conducting sitting at a desk and hunting around the internet for ideas. Its about actual
with your would-be customers to determine if theres a problem and how you might solve it.
In practice, this stage is best implemented through interviews.

Directly observe what users do, ask what they want, and try to understand what might motivate or discourage them from using your product. The goal is to get enough information that you begin to empathize with your target audience.
It helps to create a buyer persona and a
, as well as examining the correlation between a customer, his problems, and your product (or your competitors product if yours isnt ready yet).

During the empathy phase, ask about your users latest experience related to the problem you think your product solves. Try to reveal as many pain points as possible. Imagine yourself as a doctor diagnosing a disease: the more symptoms you find, the better your diagnosis, and ultimately, the better the treatment youll give.
Buy coffee coupons or Amazon gift cards, and offer them to your audience as incentive for the interview.
: about 40 minutes to analyze your collected data plus a few minutes to define the problem statement.
: the data, a notepad, a pen.

If you did everything right in the empathy stage, your notebook should be full of problems, needs, and comments from your audience by this point. If you interviewed 10-15 people, you should have enough data to highlight their common problems. If you interviewed more than 20-30 people, youll also be able to segment those audiences a bit more to define commonalities between people of similar demographics and psychographics.

Theres no need to highlight every possible segment: two or three should be fine. Define their points of view to understand them better, and this will help you define your problem statement (a short statement of the problem your product will address).
Based on what youve learned about your customers and their context, define the challenge youll be addressing. To do that, youll unpack the observations you gathered at the empathy stage.
Take all the data you got from interviews and create a table  like the one shown in the image below  to develop a
: name, age, gender, contacts, occupation, interests, etc.
: a set of techniques for brainstorming (mind maps, sketches, screens).
Now that you know the audience and their problems, its time to generate the broadest range of possibilities to solve them that would enable you to

The ideation stage isnt about finding the right idea just yet. Its about brainstorming and creating as many ideas as possible. Here, youll sketch out different ideas, mix and remix them, rebuild others ideas, etc.
The first 5-10 ideas that come to mind during a brainstorming session are usually boring or duplicative of others. For effective marketing brainstorming, consider a 7-10-17 strategy.
Appoint a person wholl write down all the ideas.
In case of a group-wide brainstorming, organize a warm-up so all participants can get to know and get comfortable with each other.
Dont rush the product development process.
Dont gather more than 10 people for a brainstorming session.
Encourage each member of the group to share their ideas.
A brainstorming session with no topic.
A team with no motivation to create something remarkable.
A team with no problem-solving skills.
A team of people with similar mindsets: invite people with different backgrounds, not marketers only.
A team of people with competing projects.
Too many breaks during a session.
Clinging to traditional and already-developed solutions.
Being too serious during a brainstorming session.

when you develop products: travel in time, teleport, reshaping yourself, assuming different roles, filling the gaps, spying, switching brains, choosing the best ideas, building mind maps, searching for help, playing sports, no stops, a SWOT analysis, criticizing, unlimited resources, a random factor, exaggerating.
: about 40 minutes with a good layout.
Youve developed a bunch of ideas to solve a problem during brainstorming. Now its time to build a tactile representation of those solutions to ask for feedback from your audience.
During this stage, your goal is to understand what components of your idea work and dont work. Create a solution prototype (a new
, product descriptions, category, lead magnet, etc.) to see what customers think of it. The prototype is an explanation of how the product will work.

When building a prototype, dont spend too long on it. Your task here is to build an experience and let users practice it as soon as possible. Theyll experience the prototype and share their thoughts on it. (Opening and follow-up questions will help you gather feedback.)
Change the prototype based on the
, and then observe users reactions. Each prototype of your product gets you closer to the final solution.
Create several prototypes of your product. It can be an upgrade of an existing product, an additional service, or an entirely new product.

Oftentimes, your audience will reject the ideas that you initially liked. And thats what makes the design thinking method so valuable for new product development: it helps you avoid products that could have been expensive failures without the right feedback.
: minimum of 60 minutes per person, 10+ representatives of your target audience.
: prototypes, user feedback, a notebook, a pen.
: a voice recorder, a video camera. Its also good to conduct your test in a place where the product will be used in real life.

The testing phase is about gathering customer feedback on your prototype. You show them something tangible and ask, How about this? Even if a user likes the idea of the product, they may not consider its prototype the best.

If possible, recreate the environment where consumers will use the product. If its a new café design, you can use 3D models, turn on background noise that might be heard in a café, and bring coffee and croissants to the test. If its a new kitchen machine, you can rent an apartment for a day and conduct tests there.
Record everything your participants do during the test. Next, analyze your participants and identify patterns: and remember, their
can often tell you more than their words.
As the most crucial step of design thinking, 
 is the key to successfully launching your new product.

The final stage of design thinking is about staffing, funding, and mapping out your e-commerce product timeline. This is where youll determine milestones for your solution and develop a funding/long-term revenue strategy to grow your business.
Any costs youll incur, including staff and marketing.
The number of sales required to hit your revenue goals. (How will you create repeat business? Will you introduce new versions of your product later?)
Your long-term goals. (What will happen with your product in five years?)
